awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Advanced multi-locus genome engineering to enable consolidated bioprocessing for the low-cost conversion of lignocellulose to hydrocarbon fuels and products
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to test an innovative new approach to generating industrially valuable microorganisms. If successful, the new approach will be demonstrated by improving the ability of an engineered bacterium to convert components of biomass into fuel. The benefit of that research will be to help develop a technology that can convert domestically-produced, non-food biomass into fuel at a low enough cost that it can become a significant part of America’s energy solution. The United States would realize multiple benefits from the production of such low-cost cellulosic biofuels. However, realization of this objective requires innovative new approaches that meaningfully decrease the cost of conversion. 

This project seeks an innovative new approach to engineering bacterial phenotypes with an unknown genetic basis, while at the same time producing strains useful for a method of biomass conversion called Consolidated Bioprocessing (CBP). The technology will expand the complexity of phenotypes that can be developed in industrial microbes by non-directed /evolutionary methods by taking advantage of natural competence, which is the ability of some bacteria to take up DNA. The solution demonstrates the feasibility of a technique called Continuous Evolution with Multiplex Natural Transformation (CE-MuNT), in a program of selection for commercially valuable phenotypes that have a complex, uncharacterized genetic basis. By using massive and rapid genetic transfers that do not require human intervention, it may be possible to rapidly create a large set of genetically diverse mutants that can then be selected for the targeted characteristics. Importantly, the approach is not limited by the significant knowledge gaps that exist about the organism. The project will initiate studies aimed at catalytically converting biomass-derived ethanol to hydrocarbons that are suited to aviation and heavy-duty applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

Principal Investigator: Christopher Herring

Awardee: Terragia Biofuel Inc. (formerly Enchi Corp.)

Different species and strains of bacteria show different behaviors in industrial applications. For example some species only use certain sugars while others can use a wide array of different kinds. Sometimes the link between desirable traits and responsible genes is well understood, but more often this association remains obscure or is very complex.  The goal of this project was to demonstrate a new approach to transferring commercially important traits from one bacterium (DNA donor) to another (host), even when the genetic basis for those traits is not understood. The host bacterium chosen for this study was T. saccharolyticum, a species that grows at 55 degrees Celsius that was genetically modified to produce ethanol from sugars commonly found in agricultural waste and other low-cost biomass. While it can use a wide variety of sugars, there are some types of polymeric hemicellulose that it cannot break down. However, this bacterium does have the ability to take up DNA from its environment, called natural competence, and that ability was the basis of the novel method we developed. Based on studies of natural competence in other organisms, we expected to observe synergistic co-transformation of multiple pieces of DNA into our host, but this was not the case. Therefore, a different approach was developed, relying on sequential integration of donor DNA at various sites in the host genome.  Integration of donor DNA in this fashion could allow the generation of host variants with a range of improved properties.  In this project, selection was based on enhanced utilization of hemicellulose sugars in a fermentation process. Our results demonstrated successful integration of the desired donor DNA, but the resulting strains did not become prevalent in the fermentor population. Further work based on genomic DNA libraries and more effective selection is likely to overcome these issues. In addition, improved strains were constructed with increased tolerance to DNA introduced from other species. For the project as a whole, a few additional months of work are likely to generate the necessary results for a successful Phase II application. Once funded, this project will help Terragia commercialize biotechnology for cost effective conversion of renewable, domestically produced lignocellulosic biomass to ethanol or other fuels.

 


Last Modified: 10/18/2024
Modified by: Christopher D Herring
